answers.answer: I used to be super fit...could leap up 3 stairs in a single bound, walk carrying a baby and 3 bags of groceries up hill for over 2 kilometres ..then I got the dreaded THYROID DISEASE...I ached all over, failed miserably in the get out of bed department, and before I knew it had turned into a blob..so I didn't bother. Too tiring anyway!BUT then something happened...First of all I had my thyroid totally removed due to a cancer scare....then I found out my close aunt got diabetes...well, I measured my waist and it was 102 cms...to avoid diabetes it should be 81 cms....so I got my butt up and started to do itty bitty bits of excersise...and now only a few months later I have lost a whole 10 kilos!I still get total exhaustion but I think having men look at me again and my ex-boyfriend now starting to think he wants to be my boyfriend again, and the diabetes scare sure are helping!Just take it slow and mark on a calendar what you did...that's how I started.. you then see what you did and you realise it felt good to see the progress!Good luck!

Okay, I'll hold you accountable. Don't you owe it to yourself to be the best YOU you can be?  I tell my kids this all time....you only get one body in this lifetime and it's up to you to take care of it.  Get off your butt and quit making excuses. There. Feel guilty now?  :)I do exercise everyday, it's part of who I am and it empowers me.  I'm 42 and I started running about 12 years ago.  Started out just walking with a girlfriend everyday and then she moved away and I didn't have anyone to walk with. So I tried jogging a little at a time and before I knew it I able to run miles without stopping. She moved back and we started running together and eventually we were running about 10 miles most days of the week.  During that time I had a hysterectomy and within 2 weeks of my surgery I was running again.  I was always the stick skinny girl with no shape and suddenly I had an athletic looking body and I liked that!  I liked that I could keep up with my kids, play soccer with them, take them to the park and go all day.  Now, I'm older and I'm definitely not running 10 miles anymore but I do make it about 4 or so most days of the week. And the best thing is that I believe I set an example for my teenage son and daughter.  Yes, mom had cancer and was so sick for about 6 months. But during that hypohe// I was still out walking a mile or so when I could barely function. I did it for ME. I did it for THEM.  I'm strong, I'm fit and I kicked cancer's butt.  Do it for YOU.
